newsitem.title: FRANCE: SOCCER-FRENCH MANAGER WORRIED ABOUT FOREIGN LEGION.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-FRENCH MANAGER WORRIED ABOUT FOREIGN LEGION.

text.p: French manager Aime Jacquet, concerned by France's lacklustre 1-0 win over Sweden in a soccer friendly on Wednesday, warned on Thursday the exodus of some of the country's most gifted players may be to blame.
Jacquet singled out three who play in Italy, hinting that their careers in Europe's strongest domestic league had harmed France's preparations for next year's World Cup.
The manager said the absence of Didier Deschamps of Juventus, who also missed France's previous match against the Netherlands, had seriously hurt the French.
"In the European championship semifinal, Deschamps was not there and we were ousted. Didier is a guy who has a real power over the rest of the team," Jacquet said.
"He is capable of putting the team back in place. Patrick Vieira and Claude Makelele played a decent match against Sweden but with Deschamps, they would not have been the same," he added.
Deschamps missed the Netherlands match last month with a knee injury and the Sweden game with dental problems.
Jacquet even said he may be forced to change the team dramatically were Deschamps to miss next June's Tournoi de France with England, Italy and Brazil.
Jacquet also admitted he had not found the right way to pair Zinedine Zidane of Juventus and Youri Djorkaeff of Internazionale.
"To do without one or the other would be a waste. There must be a solution," he said.
The French manager added he was worried about striker Christophe Dugarry, who has not played often since he left Bordeaux for AC Milan at the end of last season.
"I keep him alive because of his qualities. It's only a matter of playing. I have faith in him but I hope he'll find a club in which he plays regularly. Otherwise..."
Otherwise Jacquet made it clear that players who are not first choice players in their clubs would not be called up by France for the World Cup.
